pros: Overall, the culture with Wells Fargo is pretty decent, so no complaints there. You get pretty much all the holidays off with pay, and once you hit 3 years you get another 40hours of PTO. Also, the bonuses are nice if you've performed well for the prior year.
cons:
During the Fall of 2021 the CEO sent an email out that praised the companies performance and metrics. In it he stated that he expected those results to maintain and/or go up, even once everyone began to return to the office. Now (at least in my department) we have WFH implemented, but it's on a weekly rotating schedule (e.g., 1 week in, 1 week at home), while some departments do 3 days in the office and 2 days at home each week. I guess it's nice that they are allowing it now, but when outside circumstances that you have no control over arise during your in-office week or day, you are not allowed to work from home, even though we successfully did it for the past 2+ years. Now, if you're not feeling well (but you're able to work still), or if an unforeseen emergency arises, you MUST use a PTO day, which really sucks because the PTO and Sick Time buckets are the same, so it feels like you're being punished for not coming in to an office site when you are fully capable of actually doing the work. This wouldn't apply to all employees obviously, just those who have WFH capabilities. 

Please believe me when i say Wells Fargo is VERY strict/tyrannical with respect to WFH. Had it not been for the COVID-19 pandemic, a large number of employees wouldn't have ever had the chance to WFH, but the pandemic literally forced the company to shift and make it possible. I'm a salaried employee with no client interaction at all, so there is literally no reason for me to be in an office. Just yesterday I had an emergency on the freeway while on my way to work, and was ultimately not able to get to the office. I called my leader, updated them on everything, and even stated I could provide proof so that they knew I was not taking advantage of anything. The response was, "you'll need to use a PTO day".

review_title: High Pressure to Meet Unrealistic Goals
pros: Pay is tied to production, so the more you do, the more they compensate you because you are making the company money. Good 401k match at 6%.
cons:
Have you seen the Netflix series called, “Dirty Money - the Wagon Wheel”? If you are considering working for Wells Fargo, you have to watch this film first because that’s how your life will be at Wells Fargo.

Wells Fargo bank is still conducting business by pressuring employees, with unrealistic goals and intimidating tactics for employees to meet goals. Similar to what led to the fake account scandal, managers are using high pressure tactics on mortgage loan underwriters to produce more loans, tying incentives to production to make them underwrite and approve more and threatening to fire employees if they don’t meet the goals. Goals are unrealistic and a very small percentage of workers are able to meet these goals (1.3 loans per day while managing 30 to 50 plus files monthly). Many underwriters than compromise quality to rush through files by cutting corners in hopes they don’t get audited.
